newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan state nuclear firm head questioned by police.
newsitem.headline: Japan state nuclear firm head questioned by police.

text.p: The head of Japan's troubled state-run nuclear power firm was summoned for questioning by police on Wednesday as part of an investigation into a falsified report on a nuclear plant accident in March.
A spokesman at the Power Reactor and Nuclear Fuel Development Corp (PNC) said its president, Toshiyuki Kondo, had been summoned by police. He declined to elaborate.
It is the first time Kondo has been questioned by Ibaraki prefectural police about the March 11 accident at a nuclear fuel reprocessing plant in Tokaimura, Ibaraki.
An Ibaraki police spokesman said he had no information on the case, but Kyodo news agency quoted police sources as saying Kondo was being questioned as a witness over the false report.
The Pacific coast plant operated by PNC was the scene of Japan's worst-ever nuclear accident when a fire and explosion exposed some 37 workers to low levels of radiation.
The company came under heavy public criticism when it later emerged that the initial report on the accident was falsified.
It was not the first time the PNC had faced public ire.

Its prototype fast-breeder reactor Monju, on the Sea of Japan coast, has remained closed since a 1995 accident in which sodium coolant leaked. No radiation leaked into the environment as a result of that incident.
An investigation revealed that PNC had tried to play down the scale of the accident by keeping secret a videotape of the scene and only making public edited video footage.
A PNC official who was questioning colleagues as part of an in-house investigation committed suicide after the revelations.

In April this year, the Science and Technology Agency ordered the PNC to halt operations of its Fugen advanced heavy-water reactor after learning that the firm had delayed reporting a radiation leakage.
A full-scale review of the PNC's business is now under way and some of the firm's operations are due to be scrapped or transferred to the private sector.
Key operations will be maintained, however. These are the fast-breeder reactor development programme and research and development on the management of radioactive waste.
